Bank Notes (Ireland) Bill.MEMORANDUM.Under the existing law, which dates from 1828, banks of issue in Ireland, are bound to pay their notes on demand at their local branches, instead of being free, as such banks in Scotland and most British Colonies are, to pay at their head offices only.It is proposed by the Bill, which is introduced at the unanimous request of the banks of issue in Ireland, to relieve them of this liability, by making existing notes payable only at the head offices in Ireland and leaving the banks free to determine where future notes are to he payable.
